content: Consideration of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA)

tag: html body div div div div span article div div p strong span
html body div div div div span article div div p span
content: Due to federal court orders, USCIS has resumed accepting requests to renew a grant of deferred action under DACA. USCIS is not accepting requests from individuals who have never before been granted deferred action under DACA. Until further notice, and unless otherwise provided in this guidance, the DACA policy will be operated on the terms in place before it was rescinded on Sept. 5, 2017. For more information, visit

tag: html body div div div div span article div div p a span
content: Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals: Response to January 2018 Preliminary Injunction.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: This page provides information on requesting consideration of deferred action for childhood arrivals (DACA). You may request DACA for the first time or renew your existing period of DACA if it is expiring.

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li a span
content: Don’t Be a Victim of Immigration Scams

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li a span
html body div div div div span article div h2 span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: On June 15, 2012, the Secretary of Homeland Security announced that certain people who came to the United States as children and meet several guidelines may request consideration of deferred action for a period of two years, subject to renewal. They are also eligible for work authorization. Deferred action is a use of prosecutorial discretion to defer removal action against an individual for a certain period of time. Deferred action does not provide lawful status.

tag: html body div div div div span article div h2 span
html body div div div div span article div h2 span
content: Request DACA for the First Time

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: The following information explains the guidelines for requesting DACA for the first time. If you need further information and cannot find it in our Frequently Asked Questions, you can call the USCIS Contact Center at 800-375-5283. For people who are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech disability:TTY 800-767-1833. Representatives are available Monday-Friday from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. in each U.S. time zone.

tag: html body div div div div span article div h2 span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: You may request DACA if you:

tag: html body div div div div span article div ol li span
content: Were under the age of 31 as of June 15, 2012;

tag: html body div div div div span article div ol li span
content: Came to the United States before reaching your 16th birthday;

tag: html body div div div div span article div ol li span
content: Have continuously resided in the United States since June 15, 2007, up to the present time;

tag: html body div div div div span article div ol li span
content: Were physically present in the United States on June 15, 2012, and at the time of making your request for consideration of deferred action with USCIS;

tag: html body div div div div span article div ol li span
content: Had no lawful status on June 15, 2012;

tag: html body div div div div span article div ol li span
content: Are currently in school, have graduated or obtained a certificate of completion from high school, have obtained a general education development (GED) certificate, or are an honorably discharged veteran of the Coast Guard or Armed Forces of the United States; and

tag: html body div div div div span article div ol li span
content: Have not been convicted of a felony, significant misdemeanor,or three or more other misdemeanors, and do not otherwise pose a threat to national security or public safety.

tag: html body div div div div span article div h3 span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Anyone requesting DACA must have been under the age of 31 as of June 15, 2012. You must also be at least 15 years or older to request DACA, unless you are currently in removal proceedings or have a final removal or voluntary departure order, as summarized in the table below:

tag: html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span
html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span

content: I have never been in removal proceedings, or my proceedings have been terminated before making my request.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: At least 15 years old at the time of submitting your request and under the age of 31 as of June 15, 2012.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: I am in removal proceedings, have a final removal order, or have a voluntary departure order, and I am not in immigration detention.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: Under the age of 31 as of June 15, 2012, but you may be younger than 15 years old at the time you submit your request.

content: Use the most recent version of the form linked on our website or USCIS will reject your form.

content: Please review the Filing Fee section of the Forms I-821D

content: and I-765 pages for detailed information.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p strong span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td a span

html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p a span

html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li font strong span
content: You must file the most recent version of Form I-821D from our website. USCIS will reject older versions of the form if you submit them.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Write your name, date of birth, and mailing address exactly the same way on each form.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: We prefer that you download the forms from

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li a span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: , fill them out electronically, and then print your completed forms to mail.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Make sure you are using the most current version of the forms. The correct, most current edition of every USCIS form is always available for free download on our website.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: If you complete the forms by hand, use black ink only. Do NOT use highlighters or red ink on your forms. These could make your materials unreadable when scanned.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: If you must make changes on a form, we recommend that you begin with a new form, rather than trying to white out information. This can lead to scanning errors.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Ensure that you provide all required supporting documentation and evidence.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Be sure to sign all of your forms.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p strong span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: USCIS will reject your request if you fail to submit Forms I-821D, I-765, I-765WS, and the correct fees.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Organize and label your evidence by the DACA guideline that it meets.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Be sure that you mail all pages of the forms.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Mail the forms to correct USCIS Lockbox.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: You cannot e-file your DACA request.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: If you have questions, call the USCIS Contact Center at

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: ; do NOT visit a USCIS field office.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p strong span
content: Mail your forms to the appropriate USCIS Lockbox.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p a span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: for Form I-821D. Include the required forms, fees and supporting documentation with your filing. Remember to carefully follow instructions and fully complete your forms. USCIS will not accept incomplete forms or forms without proper fee. USCIS will mail you a receipt after accepting your request. You may also choose to receive an email and/or text message notifying you that your form has been accepted by completing a

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p a span
content: Form G-1145, E-Notification of Application/Petition Acceptance

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: UPDATE: Create a USCIS online account for DACA requests.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: Beginning February 1, 2016, anyone who submits a DACA request will be able to create a USCIS online account to track and manage his or her case online. If you submit a DACA request, you will receive a USCIS Account Acceptance Notice in the mail with instructions on how to create a USCIS online account.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: Having a USCIS online account allows you to:

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Check the status of your case;

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Receive notifications and case updates; and

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Manage your contact information, including updating your address.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: If you are an attorney or accredited representative, creating a USCIS online account will allow you to manage all of your clients’ DACA requests in one place. USCIS will continue processing your DACA request even if you choose not to access your USCIS online account. You will continue to receive notifications and updates about your case by mail through the U.S. Postal Service.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: Note for Attorneys and Accredited Representatives: You should have only one USCIS online representative account. When you receive an Account Acceptance Notice for a paper form filed at a USCIS Lockbox on behalf of your client, please ensure that you enter the same personal information that you provided on the Form G-28 submitted with your client’s original application, petition, or request. If the information you use to access your online representative account does not match the information you provided on the Form G-28, you may be unable to access your client’s case.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p strong span
content: Visit an Application Support Center (ASC) for biometric services

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: After USCIS receives your complete request with fees, we will send you a notice scheduling you to visit an ASC to for biometric services. If you fail to attend your ASC appointment, USCIS may deny your request DACA. Children under 14 in removal proceedings, with a final removal order, or with a voluntary departure order, and who are not in immigration detention, will appear at the ASC for photographs only.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p strong span
content: Check the status of your request online.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: The 90-day period for reviewing Form I-765 filed together with Form I-821D begins if and when USCIS decides to defer action in your case.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: You can check the status of your case on

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p a strong font span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: or by logging into your USCIS online account.

tag: html body div div div div span article div h2 span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: There are very limited fee exemptions available. Your request for a fee exemption must be filed and favorably adjudicated before you file your DACA request without a fee. In order to be considered for a fee exemption, you must submit a letter and supporting documentation to USCIS demonstrating that you meet one of the following conditions:

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: You are under 18 years of age, have an income that is less than 150 percent of the U.S. poverty level, and are in foster care or otherwise lacking any parental or other familial support; or,

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: You are under 18 years of age and homeless; or,

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: You cannot care for yourself because you suffer from a serious, chronic disability and your income is less than 150 percent of the U.S. poverty level; or,

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: You have, at the time of the request, accumulated $10,000 or more in debt in the past 12 months as a result of unreimbursed medical expenses for yourself or an immediate family member, and your income is less than 150 percent of the U.S. poverty level.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Submit the following types of evidence:

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: Affidavits from community-based or religious organizations to establish a requestor’s homelessness or lack of parental or other familial financial support.

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: Copies of tax returns, bank statement, pay stubs, or other reliable evidence of income level.

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: An affidavit from the applicant or a responsible third party attesting that the applicant does not file tax returns, has no bank accounts, and/or has no income to prove income level.

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: Copies of medical records, insurance records, bank statements, or other reliable evidence of unreimbursed medical expenses of at least $10,000.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: USCIS will send you a Request for Evidence (RFE) if it has questions on the evidence you submitted.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: You can find additional information on our

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Note: There are no fee waivers available for employment authorization applications connected to DACA.

tag: html body div div div div span article div h3 span
content: If USCIS Grants DACA in Your Case

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: If USCIS grants DACA and employment authorization in your case, you will receive a written notice of that decision. An Employment Authorization Document will arrive separately in the mail.

tag: html body div div div div span article div h3 span
content: If USCIS Does Not Grant DACA in Your Case

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: If USCIS decides not to grant DACA in your case, you cannot appeal the decision or file a motion to reopen or reconsider. USCIS will not review its discretionary determinations.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: We will apply our policy guidance governing the referral of cases to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the issuance of notices to appear. If your case does not involve a criminal offense, fraud, or a threat to national security or public safety, we will not refer your case to ICE for purposes of removal proceedings except where DHS determines there are exceptional circumstances. For more information on notices to appear, visit

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div h3 span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: You may request a review using the Service Request Management Tool process if you met all of the DACA guidelines and you believe USCIS denied your request because of an administrative error.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: USCIS believes you abandoned your case by not responding to a request for evidence (RFE), and you believe you did respond within the prescribed time; or

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: USCIS mailed the RFE to the wrong address, even though you had submitted a Form AR-11, Change of Address, or changed your address online at

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li a span
html body div div div div span article div ul li span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: You can find a full list of possible errors in our

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: To make a service request, you must call the USCIS Contact Center at 800-375-5283. For people who are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech disability: TTY 800-767-1833. A USCIS representative will then forward your request to the proper USCIS office. Your service request will be reviewed for accuracy and USCIS will send you a letter informing you of its decision.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: The USCIS Contact Center is now open Monday – Friday from 8 a.m. – 8 p.m. in each U.S. time zone.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div h2 span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Certain travel outside the United States may affect the continuous residence guideline. Traveling outside the U.S. before Aug. 15, 2012, will not interrupt your continuous residence if the travel was brief, casual, and innocent. If you travel outside the United States after Aug. 15, 2012, and before we decide your request for DACA, you will not be considered for DACA.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: The following chart explains whether your travel will affect your continuous residence.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span
html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span
html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: On or after June 15, 2007, but before Aug. 15, 2012

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Because of an order of exclusion, deportation, or removal

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: After Aug. 15, 2012, and before you have requested DACA

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: Yes. You cannot apply for advance parole unless and until DHS has determined whether to defer action in your case and you cannot travel until you receive advance parole.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: After Aug. 15, 2012, and after you have requested DACA

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: Yes. You cannot travel while your request is under review. You cannot apply for advance parole unless and until DHS has determined whether to defer action in your case.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: In addition, if you have previously been ordered deported and removed and you depart the United States without taking additional steps to address your removal proceedings, your departure will likely result in your being considered deported or removed, with potentially serious future immigration consequences.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: On or after Aug. 15, 2012, and receiving DACA

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: It depends. If you travel after receiving advance parole, the travel will not interrupt your continuous residence. However, if you travel without receiving advance parole, the travel will interrupt your continuous residence.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Once USCIS has approved your request for DACA, you may file

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: , Application for Travel Document, to request advance parole to travel outside of the United States. If you travel outside the United States without first receiving advance parole, USCIS will automatically terminate your DACA.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: USCIS is currently updating its policy on granting advanced parole for DACA recipients. Please check the

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div h2 span
content: National Security and Public Safety Guidelines

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: You will not be considered for DACA if you have been convicted of:

tag: html body div div div div span article div ul li span
html body div div div div span article div ul li span
html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: Three or more other misdemeanor offenses not occurring on the same date and not arising out of the same act, omission, or scheme of misconduct.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div ul li span
content: You are otherwise deemed to pose a threat to national security or public safety.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p strong span
content: What is the difference between “significant misdemeanor”, “non-significant misdemeanor”, and “felony”?

tag: html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span
html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span
html body div div div div span article div table thead tr th span
html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td span
content: A felony is a federal, state or local criminal offense punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one year.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: A significant misdemeanor is a misdemeanor as defined by federal law (specifically, one for which the maximum term of imprisonment authorized is one year or less but greater than five days) and:

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ol li span
content: Regardless of the sentence imposed, is an offense of domestic violence; sexual abuse or exploitation; burglary; unlawful possession or use of a firearm; drug distribution or trafficking; or, driving under the influence; or,

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ol li span
content: If not an offense listed above, is one for which the individual was sentenced to time in custody of more than 90 days. The sentence must involve time to be served in custody, and therefore does not include a suspended sentence.

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td p span
content: A crime is considered a non-significant misdemeanor (maximum term of imprisonment is one year or less but greater than five days) if it:

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ol li span
content: Is not an offense of domestic violence; sexual abuse or exploitation; burglary; unlawful possession or use of a firearm; drug distribution or trafficking; or, driving under the influence; and

tag: html body div div div div span article div table tbody tr td ol li span
content: Is one for which the individual was sentenced to time in custody of 90 days or less.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: A minor traffic offense will not be considered a misdemeanor for purposes of DACA, However, driving under the influence is a significant misdemeanor regardless of the sentence. You can find detailed information in the

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
content: National Security and Public Safety section

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div h2 span
content: Don’t Be a Victim of Immigration Scams

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Dishonest practitioners may promise to provide you with faster services if you pay them a fee. These people are trying to scam you and take your money. Visit our

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: page to learn how you can protect yourself from immigration scams.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Make sure you seek information about DACA from official government sources such as USCIS or the Department of Homeland Security. If you are seeking legal advice, visit our

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: page to learn how to choose a licensed attorney or accredited representative.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Remember you can download all USCIS forms for free at

tag: html body div div div div span article div p a span
html body div div div div span article div p span
html body div div div div span article div h2 span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: USCIS is committed to safeguarding the integrity of the immigration process. If you knowingly and willfully provide materially false information on Form I-821D, you will be committing a federal felony punishable by a fine, or imprisonment up to five years, or both, under 18 U.S.C. Section 1001. In addition, individuals may be placed into removal proceedings, face severe penalties provided by law, and be subject to criminal prosecution.

tag: html body div div div div span article div h2 span
html body div div div div span article div p strong span
html body div div div div span article div p strong span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: We are aware that some DACA requestors may have experienced delays receiving their Application Support Center biometrics appointment notices. We recently mailed biometrics appointment notices to those whose notices were delayed. Most of these appointments will be scheduled during the week of October 24, 2016, and we encourage you to appear at your appointment as scheduled. If you need to reschedule an appointment, please follow the instructions on your appointment notice. We will only reschedule a biometrics appointment if you have a compelling reason For more information, please refer to our guidance on rescheduling appointments due to reasons such as illness. For further information about your DACA request, you may call the USCIS Contact Center or send us an email from your online account inbox.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p strong span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: Due to a federal court order, USCIS will not begin accepting requests for the expansion of DACA on February 18 as originally planned. The court's temporary injunction, issued February 16, does not affect the existing DACA. Individuals may continue to come forward and request an initial grant of DACA or renewal of DACA under the guidelines established in 2012 and discussed below.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p strong span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: If you submitted a request for DACA renewal between February 14 and May 14, 2016, your renewal request may have taken longer than expected. You should receive a decision on your case within the next few weeks. USCIS is dedicated to restoring normal processing times as quickly as possible.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p strong span
html body div div div div span article div p span
content: The Supreme Court’s 4-4 decision on June 23, 2016, in United States v. Texas does not affect existing policy regarding 2012 Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA). Individuals who meet the 2012 DACA guidelines may continue to come forward and file an initial or renewal request for DACA under the 2012 guidelines.

tag: html body div div div div span article div p span
content: The Supreme Court decision does, however, mean that the injunction prohibiting implementation of Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) and expanded DACA remains in effect

tag: html body div div div div span article div p strong span
html body div div div div span article div p span

The court's temporary injunction, issued February 16, does not affect the existing DACA. Individuals may continue to come forward and request an initial grant of DACA or renewal of DACA under the guidelines established in 2012 and discussed below. Please check back for updates.
